first_title: Building and Consuming a RESTful API

title: Who am I?

body: As most commonly implemented, a RESTful API is a predictable and useful way to transmit data from a server to any number of clients using HTTP.
title: What's a RESTful API?

body: The RESTful convention is used throughout the internet to provide data that powers many of our daily interactions.
title: Why should I care?

body: Representational state transfer (REST) is an architectural style consisting of a coordinated set of constraints applied to components, connectors, and data elements, within a distributed hypermedia system.
title: What is REST?

body: The client does not know how the server stores its data and the server does not care how the client presents it.
title: Client-server

body: Every request stands on its own and contains all the necessary information to complete the request.
title: Stateless

body: Given the same input, one should expect the same result.
title: Idempotence

body: The server must define the ability to cache, or not, where applicable.
title: Cacheable

body: The data interface must be general enough that many clients could use it.
title: Uniform Interface

body: Construct your resources such that they are representative of the way you want your user to manipulate them.
